newsitem.title: USA: Dlr ends mixed in US, yen up on trade/rate worries.
newsitem.headline: Dlr ends mixed in US, yen up on trade/rate worries.

text.p: Dollar/mark was propped up by a strong U.S. stock market, but dollar/yen ended lower after signs of trade troubles with Japan and fears of higher Japanese interest rates bolstered the yen.
Dollar/mark got support in the U.S. from bids near 1.71 after falling from 1.7169, a new 34-month high set in Asia.

The early rally sputtered as dollar/yen turned sharply lower after a report showed Japan's trade surplus jumped in early February and U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said the U.S. was very "watchful" of its trade deficit with Japan.

"Rubin made a few comments overnight and the Japanese trade number came out showing an increase in the surplus and of course that has helped the yen," said Dennis Pettit, foreign exchange manager at Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan.

The dollar ended at 121.20/30 yen, down from 121.35/40 at the open. It fetched 1.7125/35 marks slightly more than 1.7112/17. Traders said the dollar got a lift, after earlier sliding to 1.7091 marks, as Wall Street stocks were bid up.
"The stock market is kind of bid which is supportive to the dollar," said Kisoo Park, senior dealer at Bank of Boston. "I think there are definitely some orders to buy."
The Dow Jones Industrial stock average was up more than 93 points at the end of trade on Wednesday.
Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus swelled more than 53 percent to 197.33 billion yen in the first 20 days of February, compared with one year ago.

Mark/yen tumbled below 71 overnight, its lowest since last June, after Japan's chief government spokesman, Seiroku Kajiyama told a parliamentary committee that Japan needs to consider measures to deal with the adverse impact of low interest rates on personal incomes.
The cross hit a low near 70.70 yen in U.S. dealings.

"Also last night, a government spokesman from Japan was talking about being worried about interest rates, so there were a couple of reasons for people to perhaps buy back some yen here," said Keith Woodfin, currency analyst at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
With yields on Japanese financial instruments among the lowest in the world, pensioners in particular have lobbied the goverment hard to improve the returns on their retirement savings, Woodfin said.
The specter of higher Japanese interest rates increased the relative attractiveness of yen-denominated investments and made investors hesitant to buy dollars for yen, traders said.
But against the mark, interest rate spreads should continue to favor the dollar because German interest rates are expected to remain low, while U.S. rates could increase.

The financial markets were looking for more clues about U.S. interest rates from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who completed his semi annual Humphrey-Hawkins testimony on the U.S. economy and interest rate outlook before the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday.

The markets were upbeat after Greenspan's comments, even though they were a close replay of his address last week when he told a Senate panel the Fed could tighten credit even before solid signs of inflation emerge.
Elsewhere, the dollar rose to 1.4820/30 Swiss francs from 1.4815/20 at the open and to Canadian $1.3683/88 from C$1.3676/81.
The pound rose to $1.6133/43 from $1.6100/05 and the Australian dollar was at $0.7842/47, compared with $0.7845/50.
